posts.title: CLIFF WALLACE at MILKandLEAD
posts.content:
CLIFF WALLACE works as a special effects makeup artist in England. he started his career on Clive Barker ‘s Hellraiser in 1985. Since then he has worked on over fifty movies including films for Ken Russell, Brian De Palma, Ridley Scott, Danny Boyle, Guillermo Del Toro and Steven Spielberg.

Since 2009 he has been exhibiting sculptures at galleries throughout Europe and the United States.

Traditionally his sculptures are made first in clay, then moulded in silicone and cast in translucent resin.

More details about Cliff Walllace and his company creature effects, can be found at www.creature-effects.com

posts.title: Lee Adams at MILKandLEAD דיאליזה
posts.content:
The Sacred Conspirancy

“Man has escaped from his head just as the condemned man has escaped from his prison. He has found beyond himself not God, who is the prohibition against crime, but a being who is unaware of prohibition. Beyond what I am, I meet a being who makes me laugh because he is headless; this fills me with dread because he is made of innocence and crime; He holds a steel weapon in his left hand, flames like those of a Sacred Heart in his right. He reunites in the same eruption Birth and Death. He is not a man. He is not a god either. He is not me but he is more than me: his belly is the labyrinth in which he has lost himself, loses me with him, and in which I discover myself as him, in other words as a monster.”

Georges Bataille – The Sacred Conspiracy, from Visions of Excess – Selected Writings 1927 – 1939

The Sacred Conspirancy, performed as part of Ron Athey‘s History of Ecstasy, co-commisioned by Museo d’Arte Contemporanea Donna Regina (MADRE) and Napoli Teatro Festival Italia. 2009.

 

 

 

Video and Editing:

Karolina Urbaniak

http://karolinaurbaniak.com/

posts.title: Valentina Bardazzi and Mirco Magnani
posts.content:
REALDREAM is the attempt of professing through out art works the following idea:
“True perfection does not exist, the sense of beauty comes from imperfection.”
The artists see the human body as a sensor – an antenna, if you will – that contains, measures and absorbs objects, thoughts and waves, and with this idea in mind, they go look deeper into the layer of skin in which everything absorbed from daily life remains entangled—the owner of the body does not need to speak of their experiences; the bodies speaks on its own.
The collaboration between these two artists started in late 2007 when Mirco Magnani and Valentina Bardazzi began to use the same subjects for the paintings and to make videos. The imagery is quite remarkable, because without knowing this, one would think that perhaps they were simply two artists working with the same living model. To the mix, he added his own music compositions, bringing to life again the immortally frozen human forms.

posts.title: Patricide Return for St George’s Day Telepathic Triptych
posts.title_plain: Patricide Return for St George’s Day Telepathic Triptych
posts.content:
Patricide for this occasion were Aryan Darzi, GazCloud and James Hollands. We had gotten used to doing an annual St George’s Day celebration – we all had an interest in tropes surrounding England – and to be able to perform in the East End of London for St. George’s Day was a dream.I’d just come back from doing a triple screen installation of my film “Telepathy 101′, opening a gallery called Divus in Prague and Aryan suggested doing a multi-projector set-up. It would be four projectors in the end, one upstairs three downstairs. The basement in the gallery was a perfect setting, surrounded by Iris Scheiferstein’s scupltures.We scored a hole through the window upstairs and projected “St George Was A Cunt” onto the white walls of the building opposite.A truckload of people tumbled out of the ambulance having driven from the squat down the road. Then I remember enticing some people we didn’t know into the gig. God knows what they must have made of the aural, visual and chemical proceedings.I can’t remember the rest of the night.

James B.L. Hollands, September 2012

Triple screen installation : Telepathy 101 by James B.L. Hollands, Telepathy 101 (remix) by Aryan Darzi with live soundtrack by Patricide (for this show, Aryan Darzi, Gaz Cloud and James B.L. Hollands)
Additional outdoor 15 foot projection for St George’s Day of “St. George Was A Cunt” video by James B.L. Hollands.
Flyer by Aryan Darzi. Photos by Erin Sanna.

posts.title: EATEN BY CHILDREN
posts.content:
It’s just me and a load of junk. The name actually came about from a conversation I was having with my girlfriend about a play she had just finished reading – Suddenly Last Summer by Tennessee Williams. The whole play is haunted by the absence of a character, and specifically the mysterious reason for his disappearance. It later transpires that, whilst in Europe, he was eaten alive by a group of young boys. Anyway, I was looking for a name at the time and my girlfriend said ‘why don’t you call your music eaten by children?’. It’s not really meant as an allusion to the play – I like the fact that it’s a very strong, emotionally charged image and at the same time fairly ambiguous – “what is being eaten by children, why?”
There’s probably thousands of influences floating around but I’d say there are two main ones that inform pretty much everything I do – Smog and Nurse With Wound. Smog because his output is so personal – you sometimes feel like you’re locked in a confessional with him when listening to his records. I’ve really tried to create a similar level of intimacy on this album. Of course, an “intimate noise record” might sound like a complete contradiction in terms to a lot of people, but to me there’s something incredibly personal and introspective about the total intensity and immersion you can experience from a great noise record. As Mark E Smith once said, “it really cleans your head out”

Nurse With Wound really informed the eclecticism of the album. He’s one of the only musicians who explores surrealist ideas with a real level of conviction. The really disruptive, sharp cuts on his “Spiral Insana” album were a really important reference point for me, as well as the hypnotic soundscapes on stuff like “Homotopy to Marie”. I’m also really influenced by a lot of avant-garde films, the trance states induced by Stan Brakhage’s flicker films or the deadpan humour in John Smith’s work

Rob Hart

from the interview by Heathen Harvest
posts.excerpt: It’s just me and a load of junk. The name actually came about from a conversation I was having with my girlfriend about a play she had just finished reading – Suddenly Last Summer by Tennessee Williams. The whole play […]

wpcf-exhibition_intro: Through the dark he makes you watch the sound, with more projectors miked and with the mixture of chemicals can project a burst of images and sounds while maintaining the image and sound to create tension and collapse, explosion of images and sounds. In addition to this a very strong smell of the products he uses. In our opinion, one of the first exponents.

posts.title: IRIS SCHIEFERSTEIN
posts.content:
February 2011, the gallery MILKandLEAD hosted the solo exhibition of the Berlin artist.
Iris Schieferstein portrays the creation of “creatures” formed by one or more different animals already found lifeless, chosen and taken to the laboratory of the artist, where they are recomposed and stitched together with the mastery of taxidermy; evolving into something different thus enabling the audience to sense its suppleness and the harmony of its shapes and its strengths, or in this very case the aura and the gift of endless life.
Accidentally the arrival of the Berlin artist coincides with the 160th anniversary of the death of the well-known writer from London, Mary Shelly ( August 1797/February 1851), creator of the fictitious character “Frankenstein”.
The affinity between the main character of the book and the artist is joined up to restore the soul to an inanimate matter but then it is divided in two exact opposites. The creatures of Iris Schiefestein do not appear deformed or lacking of grace, but of a measured and sublime physical shape where the observer is being led in a surreal and fable reality, in some cases they are romantically transformed in letters.
by FrancescoVertucci (ArtCurator)
posts.excerpt: February 2011, the gallery MILKandLEAD hosted the solo exhibition of the Berlin artist. Iris Schieferstein portrays the creation of “creatures” formed by one or more different animals already found lifeless, chosen and taken to the laboratory of the artist, where they are recomposed […]

wpcf-exhibition_intro: The German goverment once tried to put the artist in the jail for her taxidermy art but , as she explains, her work gives life and reanimation to the creatures  she uses

posts.title: VERA BREMERTON
posts.content: This is what infuses Vera Bremerton’s passionate songs. Pounding techno beats and the thrashing sound of industrial machinery merge with sensual synths and raw guitar, like scalpels carving a work of art out of live flesh and pulsating nerves. Vera’s acrobatic and unpredictable vocal melodies, spanning though four octaves, give voice to the silent screams that only happen in dreams. In one word, her music is “Elemental”, just like the title of her first CD.
posts.excerpt: This is what infuses Vera Bremerton’s passionate songs. Pounding techno beats and the thrashing sound of industrial machinery merge with sensual synths and raw guitar, like scalpels carving a work of art out of live flesh and pulsating nerves. Vera’s […]

wpcf-exhibition_intro: The everlasting battle between instinct and rationality in one’s soul. The dark forces of nature and the piercing light of culture.
wpcf-artist_bio:
I was born and bred in Italy where I was classically trained as a pianist and a singer. This “imprinting” had a strong influence on my compositional style in terms of harmony and arrangement. Nevertheless, in more recent times I have also come into contact with the harshest styles of industrial, metal and avantgarde music, and developed a taste for aggressive electronic sounds and pounding beats. I have also radically expanded my vocal skills and become specialised in a number of extended techniques (think Diamanda Galàs, Jarboe, Cathy Berberian).

After moving to London I began to compose music on a regular basis, which resulted in a self-financed CD of early songs called Elemental, released in 2010, and in a four tracks noise/power electronics promo simply named Vera Bremerton, recorded at home in 2011.

I have played various events including the Sound11 festival at The Sage Gateshead, electronic all-nighter Noise=Noise and several ILL FM nights which were broadcast at www. illfm.net. “Cry Little Sister”, a cover of the theme song from The Lost Boys, was released in Italy on Fight Night 2010, a compilation distributed by Italian film website i400calci.com. My songs have been broadcast during various shows on radioukinternational.com, radiobasingstoke.co.uk and coventgardenradio.com. My latest composition, Interior Castle, was inspired by the works of Teresa of Avila and her experience of mystical ecstasy and union with God. It was premiéred at Cambridge University within a conference called Music And Transcendence. I think this "a cappella" work represents a stepping stone in my compositional and vocal skills.

posts.title: VERDIANA RAW

wpcf-exhibition_intro: The ethereal voice, a piano and a guitar. The atmosphere is arcane,esoteric, penetrating in the crack in the echo of the subconscious.
wpcf-artist_bio:
Verdiana Raw is an italian
raw-ethereal,
esoteric music project,
born in 2010.
The project is based around
Verdiana Raw’s voice and piano,
supported by
Antonio Bacchi's guitars and
Fabio Chiari's percussions.
“Verdiana Raw” is a music project born in 2010 when the singer-songwriter Verdiana Raw and the guitarist Antonio Bacchi first met. Verdiana had a classical musical education, she early studied violin but she quitted it as she  decided to explore in her own personal way a larger range of artistic expressions, including theater.  Years later, in Palermo, she turned back to her musical path by many collaborations (for instance  with Sergio Bonfiglioli): she mixed her voice with piano, keeping focus on her vocal virtuosity. Antonio, guitarist influenced by the new-wave scene and its furthers processing, grew fascinated  by the 80s music mood of his town, Firenze, but he left  music ambitions because of his work career and social commitment untill, during 2009, he finally decided to put things in order in his life and restarted a new musical path which has  brought him to meet Verdiana one year later. Their first common experience was the collaboration with the Extreme Body artist  Alexandre Fuser, as they accompanished on stage his  performances in several  dates. (...)

posts.title: Trans4LEBEN  at MILKandLEAD
posts.content:
Ernesto Tomasini (“the famous castrato-style performer” – The Evening Standard) and Josè Macabra (Antagony  – Behind Bars)

Unleash their first collaboration together, on Friday 25th March 2011 at the MILKandLEAD Art Gallery.

Ernesto Tomasini is often described by the international press as “a cult figure”. He has entertained audiences for over 20 years: from his beginnings in Italian cabaret to experimental theatre around the world, from his work with the Lindsay Kemp Company to West End musicals, from bit roles in Hollywood films to major ones on British television, not to mention his own provocative productions which he took from the Edinburgh Festival to international tours. In 2007 he begun to lend his wide vocal range to experimental music. He is co-founder of two major projects: the Othon & Tomasini duo, with composer Othon (with whom he has performed in London venues like the Roundhouse and the National Portrait Gallery and in historical theatres around Europe), and the post-rock band Almagest!, with which he has just appeared at the Volksbuehne in Berlin and the Natural History Museum in Turin. He also boasts collaborations with names like Coil’s Peter Christopherson, Nurse With Wound’s Andrew Liles and Current 93 (he was special guest at their Queen Elizabeth Hall concert, alongside Antony of Antony & the Johnsons). As soloist he has sung his repertoire in London venues like the Royal Albert Hall, the Purcell Room, the National Theatre and Tate Britain. Ernesto has performed at two editions of the London Fashion Week and, as a recording artist, has had five albums released on prestigious indie labels, plus a single and a guest spot on the soundtrack of Bruce LaBruce’s penultimate film. His next two records (his first with the band Almagest! and Othon’s second, in which he sings alongside Marc Almond and Camille O’Sullivan) will be released later on in the year. As voiceover artist he has worked for directors James Ivory, Ridley Scott and Kevin Spacey. His collaborations with Ron Athey and Stephen Montague are among his more recent forays into performance art. A sought-after lecturer on theatre history and techniques, he has given master-classes to students in drama schools in UK, Spain and Mexico. Since early 2010 he has his own column on the Italian magazine Musical!.

 

Jose Macabra was born in Toledo, Spain. With a background in psychology, he studied Digital Media and Sound Arts and Design at LCC, in London. Since graduating he has worked in various fields of the arts, quickly becoming an established musician, curator and events promoter. After starting out with the band Joan of Arc Family (supporting Sex Gang Children and Tuxedomoon) he went on to performance art, founding the group L Karma DL Trauma, which appeared at London’s 291 Gallery in 2005, supporting Ron Athey’s “Judas Cradle”. His personal and distinctive use of sound and image has taken him to perform in various locations around Europe, most notably in UK, Spain, Germany and Greece (where he created the sound for “What Scratches The Glass From The Inside” with dancer Kat Valastur, which went on an international tour). He created the music for MTV ident animations, and sound for “Will It Hurt?”, a performance by Catherine Mafioleti in London. In 2009 he devised an experimental theatre performance/ live soundtrack for “The Shining”, at the BFI in London for the Stanley Kubrick season. In 2010 he created the “Dreams and Realities” show, which he presented with a performance art troupe at the Horse Hospital, for the London Underground Film Festival. More recently he performed at the Barbican as part of Cock Number 7. He is currently working with the band Brood, a development of Hypersensorial Squadron, with which he appeared in Noise=Noise=Noise, ILL FM and Resonance FM. Jose is best known for his work on regular events in London and Berlin like Antagony, Sabbat and Behind Bars

TRANS4LEBEN

visuals: OriginalCopy

dress by Lee Benjamin (former Leigh Bowery assistant)

posts.title: MEMENTO MORI – Gunther Iscariot
posts.content:
A noisy street of central London.A door opens,we step in to an abandoned church,the grave sound leads  to a circular room, the only light are candles,there are flowers and incense.

Is “Pure Darkness”,a funeral atmosphere,a sublime pleasure.

Memento Mori (Gunther Iscariot)  live Dark Ambient concert collaborating for this event with A/Ona Alessia ( percussion) and Amir Shoat (ethnic instruments and vocals).

Photography : Magda Bondos

wpcf-exhibition_intro: "Ther's nothing left to safe,if there ever was anything....if there ever could be."
wpcf-exhibition_location: At the Church "ex limelight"  Soho london
wpcf-about_description: Central London,a very caothic street,a door opens,we are in an abandoned churc,from the corridor a keen sound leads  to a main circular room,the only light is candles all around a live dark ambient concert.A Memento Mori project  collaborating for this event with A Ona Alessia percussion and Amir Shoat.

posts.title: LILIES ON MARS
posts.content: Lilies on mars were a methaphysic concert merged to the art pieces and the odeon.The connection among all gave birth to a surreal connection.
posts.excerpt: Lilies on mars were a methaphysic concert merged to the art pieces and the odeon.The connection among all gave birth to a surreal connection.

wpcf-exhibition_intro: Matter,its waves and radiation create sounds that enthrall.Inspired by this,we play music looking up.
wpcf-artist_bio:
Lilies on Mars are Lisa Masia, and Marina Cristofalo, they met over ten years ago and were the touring and film collaborators of Italian icon Franco Battiato before forming Lilies on Mars in August 2008. Fascinated by the spirit of DIY, they produced, mixed and self-released their debut album in April 2009, mastered by Bill Gautier (The Cure- Fleet Foxes…) Shortly after, they debuted live at La Cigale Theatre in Paris with Franco Battiato and continued touring on their own in UK, Italy, Germany and USA for the whole 2009/beginning 2010.
In 2011 they released their second album Wish You Were a Pony, recorded by Lilies on Mars and Mixed by Dan Brantigan (Kaki King co-writer and musician).

posts.title: PANDEMONIA PANACEA
posts.content: Pandemonia exhibits herself at MILKandLEAD during the “Devine Comedy” exhibition.
posts.excerpt: Pandemonia exhibits herself at MILKandLEAD during the “Devine Comedy” exhibition.

wpcf-exhibition_intro: Doing two hours and forty minutes poses she intrigued onlookers. Stretching the boundaries of reality and fiction.

attachments.title: soediv 2009
attachments.description: about short film about miscalculations still life

wpcf-exhibition_intro: MILKandLEAD first opening.People arrive from outside,curious, a noise music rises from the basement of the gallery,they follow the sound,down to the spiral staircase and arrive in to a white room,where on a main wall are projected images,of 3D animation, following one another and the sounds merges on to the videos.
wpcf-artist_bio:
Vincenzo Spagnuolo was born 9 october 1984
He graduated in Set Design at the Academy of Fine Arts Naples
Since 2005 he began his research on the possibilities of graphics and stylistic
new technologies to achieve his ideas,studies and software to benefit from,the knowledge of the composition and modeling in 3D animation, which combines the traditional studies on the animation to the formation
in stage design and directing. 
Creates a very personal and artistic journey from pioneering
order to provide a visual quality that deviates from the representation or virtual  simulacrum using only the power of technology to reach a graphic balance between diagram and representation.

The first DVD pre temporal order of creation: Soediv began in 1999 where experiments alternatives to the use of hyper-realistic computer graphics ever revealing propensity toward music video.

The second DVD: Short film about miscalculations shows how the path has reached the limit of instinctivity becoming only the diagram in the abstract virtual. In fact all the videos of this collection were not created by the artist but simply collected, the videos are whether created accidentally by errors of calculation of the machine during rendering or shooting with digital cameras. There is no control in these videos by the artist who becomes only a research left to chance and the creative capacity of the machine.
Observing the DNA of the machine, receiving the error as changes or new combination and keeps the result as it evolved spontaneously.

The third DVD contains 3 courses and an outside series:
Still Life is the return of language in search of wild and instinctive awareness
applied to the bases of the new meaning of virtual representation as primitive pictures.
Landscape grammar applies to the construction of new exterior and interior in order to create a child of this universe stylistic research.
Icons applys the grammar to the figures, portraits and icons.
Tie the signifier to the signified.
The characters portrayed are: Obama, Nixon, Berlusconi, Gaddafi, Che Guevara, Fidel Castro, Hitler
out of series: These are 3 exclusive video from the series as it does not find a place clear within the course and made almost a synthesis that excludes the rest.In this case are set out in the series and also the viewer is conscious of
the difference between these videos and the balance (if there is any).

posts.title: Zelimir Baric aka ZELIKO
posts.content:
“ZELIMIR BARIC”Zeliko Baric, was born 1 .08. 1975 a Novi Sad, Serbia.live and working Milan  Italy.

There are examples in which I try to understand the iconic shape and the geometry that is always present in  nature.
I try to understand the characteristic of matter (in this case metal, which I consider the cosmic). It’s always a game with elements that are not perfect, to find a perfect shape you need for a new idea. The gradual implementation in order to dedicate all of the implementation of the idea. In this “battle” i can find all the elements to win. Now I feel freedom, which is the true meaning of my creation. Almost all of these items at biological and mechanical must perform the final test to oppose … and with that, be able to withstand the weight of the Creator, without any deformation. They must be durable.
posts.excerpt: “ZELIMIR BARIC”Zeliko Baric, was born 1 .08. 1975 a Novi Sad, Serbia.live and working Milan  Italy. There are examples in which I try to understand the iconic shape and the geometry that is always present in  nature. I try to understand the […]

wpcf-exhibition_intro: Mechanical insects come to life inside the gallery, moving from the floor to the walls.

posts.title: EMMANUELE DE RUVO
posts.content:
“PRECARIOUS EQUILIBRIA”

The art of Emmanuele De Ruvo is not, strictly speaking, performing art. As the common definition tells us, the performing arts are those forms of art which differ from the plastic arts insofar as the former uses the artist’s own body, face, and presence as a medium, and the latter uses materials such as clay, metal or paint which can be molded or transformed to create some physical art object. But there is something particular about these works, about these artistic assemblages, that makes them more than mere plastic art. On one side they act as a metaphor of ourselves and our lives; metaphors of the everlasting performance in which humanity has been involved from the start of civilisation onward. On the other side the viewers are supposed to dance carefuly around the objects, in order to preserve their fragile balance. The viewing becomes thus a breathtaking performance, leading to a higher conscience of our roles as individuals.

Eugenio Pizzorno

wpcf-exhibition_intro: “Who decides the system decides the dynamic, Who decides the dynamic describes the condition of life”
wpcf-artist_bio: Emmanuele De Ruvo was born in Napoli on November 28 1983. His mother is a painter and his father is an electrical engineer, who instills in him a passion for physics. Since a little boy Emmanuele shows great interest and passion for design and gets closer to painting through the world of the "Writing" and of the "Street Arts". He attends the Technical Institute with "construction building" orientation in Piedimonte Matese. Later he enrolls at the Fine Arts Academy in his hometown and graduates magna con laude. Technical studies coupled with physics and design studies will be the fundamental characteristic of his artistic path with a strong surrealist inspiration and passion for systems analysis. Particular attention is given to the studies of men and to the social and anthropological dynamics that determine its endeavors. He begins attending all the Academy exhibitions since 2005, where he distinguishes himself from the start and as a consequence is invited to attend even more important and prestigious art exhibits. Quickly and thanks to his great skills and capacities, Emmanuele arrives in Europe and then travels overseas. 2010 is the year of "Eruption Napoli/New York" at the White Box Gallery in Manhattan, an International project financed by Arcus, and the year of "Precarious Equilibriums" at the MILKandLEAD Gallery  London. He performs as an active actor in Herman Nitch "130 Aktion Naples" performance and he participates and wins at the "Italian Figurative Art" in Stockholm. In 2011 he is selected amongst the best artists graduated between the years 2000 and 2010 in the Italian Fine Arts Academies, to participate at the 54th Venice Biennale. He now is somewhere in this planet reflecting on how to keep in equilibrium the forces of life.
